marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Benjamin Franklin one of the founding fathers of the United States and a resident of Philadelphia, Pa. Franklin was also an author, printer, politician, postmaster, scientist, inventor, civic activist, statesman, and diplomat.

Collection includes a copy of a letter from Benjamin Franklin written on behalf of the abolition society of Pennsylvania to John Langdon, President of New Hampshire, stating that enslaved people were brought into the southern states in ships owned by residents of New Hampshire, and hoping that Langdon will put a stop to this practice.

Collection includes a letter of introduction for two young men named Mitford written by Richard Price. Price states that a great revolution has taken place in England, and that he hopes that those now in positions of Influence within the Government will prove themselves to be friends of liberty and justice, and that the war between England and the Colonies will soon be terminated.

Collection includes a print of the printing press at which Benjamin Franklin first worked as a journeyman with attached letters verifying that this press is the one at which Franklin first worked; a receipt of March 24, 1757, from Franklin to John Hughes for his gift of thirty-two dollars to the Society for Promoting Arts and Manufactures, and for eight dollars to be spent by Franklin for a thermometer and barometer. This item is framed with three lithographs of Franklin. It was transferred to President Knight's office as a permanent loan.
John Forsyth was a statesman, and governor of Georgia from Augusta (Richmond Co.), Ga.

Collection includes correspondence relating to Forsyth's service as governor of Georgia, minister to Spain, and Secretary of State. Also includes papers regarding a lawsuit of Caldcleugh, Boyd and Reid vs. John Forsyth, and letter from James Petigru.

William Temple Franklin (1760-1823) was an American diplomat and real estate speculator, who lived and died in Paris, France. William Temple Franklin was the grandson of Benjamin Franklin and editor of his works.

Collection includes a letter from George Fox (1759-1828) of Philadelphia introducing George Emlen (1784-1850) of Philadelphia who was going to Europe. Fox also discussed a problem with Franklin's land in New York.
John A. Forsyth was a merchant in Statesville (Iredell Co.), N.C.

Collection includes letters and accounts of merchants John A. and Henderson Forsyth. There are accounts of Charleston wholesalers; a letter (1837) from Thomas Reid, who describes Aberdeen, Scotland, and comments on the Reform Bill of 1832; letters of R.S. Gracy on slave trading; and letters of R.H. Carson on medical practice in Demopolis, Alabama. Many letters relate to the buying and selling of slaves.
Ellen and Susan Foster were residents of Baltimore, Md.
Collection includes letters referencing a benefit party for the sufferers of Fall River; and, a comic opera, "La Fille du Regiment".

Collection includes correspondence of three North Carolina families, the Headricks (Hedricks), Bosses, and Franks, who settled in Illinois, Missouri, Indiana, and Kentucky, regarding life on the new farmlands as compared with their previous life in North Carolina. One letter from G.W. Frank describes his course of instruction at a North Carolina school, and another from Alexander Frank to his wife, Susanna, is concerned with desertion from the Confederate Army.

Letters of George W. and Jesse M. Frank describe the movements of the 48th North Carolina Infantry in the Petersburg area, with comments on food, religion, and camp life; miscellaneous other Civil War letters of the Franks and their cousins, the Leonards, mention skirmishes in Virginia, food, and the battles of Spotsylvania Court House and of North Anna Creek.
North Anna River, Battle of, Va., 1864.
Spotsylvania Court House, Battle of, Va., 1864.
L. S. Foster was a U.S. Senator from Connecticut; from Norwich (New London Co.), Conn.

Letters from Foster to his niece, Mrs. William L. Gaylord, of Fitzwilliam, N.H., and his sister, Mrs. F.W. Hyde of Norwich, Conn. The letters are personal in nature, describing a visit of the Japanese embassy in 1860, the confusion after the first battle of Bull Run, and the behavior of the Congress while counting the electoral vote of 1869.
H. L. Franklin was a Union soldier from Vermont.
Collections includes correspondence from H.L. Franklin to his mother while he was stationed at Camp Griffin, Va., discussing food sent from home and loneliness.
Confederate soldier from Pittsylvania County, Va.

Letters discussing the Pratt hospital in Lynchburg and the Chimborazo in Richmond; supplies, food, sickness, furlough, desertions, casualties; absence without leave; Confederate generals; and the battle at Richmond.
Kate D. Foster was the daughter of James Foster, a plantation owner from Madison Parish, La.; resident of Adams County, Miss.

The majority of the entries date to the latter half of 1863 and concern the Civil War and Miss Foster's opinions about the righteousness of the Southern cause and the effect of the war on her home and on the local slaves. Postwar entries concern personal matters. The diary's inside covers are pasted with clippings of pro-Southern patriotic poetry. There is also a typescript of the entire text.
Son of Thomas Flournoy Foster, a congressman from Ga.
Collection consists of a personal letter to Thomas Gardner Foster from a cousin in Braxton Bragg's Army of Tenn.
Gustavus Vasa Fox was a resident of Washington, D.C.
Collection includes a telegram from G. V. Fox to Capt. John Ericsson ordering that an experiment on be discontinued as that ship was needed immediately off Charleston.
David Fort was a Confederate soldier and resident of Wake County, N.C.
Personal letters to his family written while Fort was stationed near Orange Court House, Va.
Martha Lyman Foster was a resident of Washington, D.C.
The collection includes letters to Martha Foster regarding Congressmen sending photographs to admirers during a war.
Collection consists of a letter, Aug. 8, 1865, to Taber & Co. discussing whaling expeditions, cartographic errors, and encounters with the C.S.S. Shenandoah.
English historian, biographer of Charles Dickens and Oliver Goldsmith.
Collection comprises letters from Forster to Frederick Chapman, head of the London publishing firm Chapman & Hall, regarding the company's publication of Thomas Carlyle's works.

Journal (15 p.), photograph, and biographical information about Foster's brother, Richard Witty Foster, a politician and government official in South Australia. The typescript journal (Aug. 1-Nov. 1, 1879) describes a voyage from England to New Zealand by Charles Foster as a young man seeking agricultural employment at his destination. After sightseeing in London, he boarded the steamship AFGHAN, taking a route to Plymouth, St. Vincent, Cape Town, the Kangaroo Islands, Melbourne and Hobart in Australia, and on to New Zealand. Foster took a train to Adelaide, South Australia, in an unsuccessful attempt to visit his brother. One entry mentions the end of the Zulu War, the Zulu king as prisoner, and returning regiments. The photograph is of Charles Foster and his second wife Margaret in the early 1930s.
John Fox, Jr. was a novelist, short story writer, and resident of Big Stone Gap, Va.

Collection includes letters from Fox to his publishers, Harper & Brothers, and "The Century." Letters of 1890-1896 are to Richard Watson Gilder and Robert Underwood Johnson of "The Century" and concern the publication of Fox's story, "A Cumberland Vendetta." Letters of 1897 are to Harper & Brothers and concern two of Fox's books, Hell-fer-Sartain and The Kentuckians. A letter of 1901, from Fox to an unidentified person named Ellen, refers to borrowing some of her ideas for his forthcoming book, Bluegrass and Rhododendron.
